Series: 'In The Shadow Of Two Gunmen Part I'

Episode.Title: In The Shadow Of Two Gunmen part 1

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: 37 P.M. Minutes after the assassination attempt, several limousines are driving down the bridge, heading back to the White House. Sirens are heard everywhere.
We have no idea on the sweep of the perimeter at this time. We have no idea...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LIMOUSINE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: President Bartlet and Special Agent Ron Butterfield are inside the moving limo.

Dialogues.Line: Zoey's secure.
Get her again.
She wasn't hit sir. She's...
Get her on the radio, please!
Sir, she can't talk right now.
Why can't she talk?
She's vomiting in the car.
Why the hell?
It happens, sir, we'll...
Why is she vomiting?
It happens.  It could be shock.
Ron...
She might have got an elbow on the stomach...
Is Gina with her?
Gina put her in the car.
She's not with her?
She's got two other agents in the car. She's got Mike and Fred, sir. They're going to have her back in the White House.
Why isn't Gina in the car?
Gina put Zoey in the car then stayed behind for the ID agent. Mr. President, please. Bartlet sighs and gasps for breath.
Is anybody dead back there?
We don't know, we don't think so. We see Ron's bloody hand, wrapped with some bandage.
What happened to your hand?!
I got hit.
Oh God. [to the driver] Coop, turn around, we gotta go to the hospital.
We got to get you to the White House.
We're going to the hospital! Let's go!
I have to put you inside the White House, Mr. President. This isn't something we discuss.

This is... my daughter is throwing up on the floor in the car behind us. You're losing blood by the liter, not to mention how many broken bones you got in your hand, but let's make sure that I'm tucked in bed before we do anything... Blood has started coming out of the President's mouth.
Mr. President? Ron quickly checks the President for a possible injury. He feels blood near Bartlet's stomach.
G.W.! Blue! Blue! Blue! The limousine makes a quick 180-degree turn.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE NEWSEUM PARKING AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: We hear sirens everywhere. The place is full of policemen, agents, paramedics and the people from the ropeline.

Dialogues.Line: Left thigh, nerovasc intact.
She's stable. Give me some 4 by 4's. Two medics are attending to C.J., who is obviously hurt and has her hand on her head.
I'm really fine.
Scalp laceration, secondary to fall. [leaves]
I hit my head on the ground.
No LOC?
Somebody pulled me down.
Are you C.J. Cregg?
Yeah!
Can you tell me what day it is?
It's still Monday.
Ok, C.J., you're more shaken up than anything else, I don't think you're going to need stitches but you should find some place to lie down.
Is the President dead?
I wouldn't know anything about that. The medic has left. C.J. walks around a police car. She notices the glass door broken. From behind, Sam approaches.
You all right?
What?
Are you all right?
Yeah, where's the President?
He's on the way back to the White House, so is Zoey, they just put Leo in the car, you all right?
Somebody pulled me down. Gina runs by.
Gina?
I can't talk right now. Gina approaches an agent.
Gina Toscano.
Tommy Cho.
Are you the I.D. agent?
Yeah.
Two shooters in that window, we got them both from the roof, but there was a signal.
There was somebody on the ground?
White male, 20, 25, maybe 5-10.
What else?
He was wearing a baseball cap.
What kind of cap?
Maybe it got knocked off from the crowd.
What kind of cap?!
I don't know.
[to an agent] Fix the perimeter, close the airports, shut them down, I want the Harbor Patrol and the Coast Guard.
You got it.
Stevie! Paul! Somewhere near, Toby is looking around for Josh.
Josh! Josh! He spots Charlie.
Hey, Charlie, are you okay?
Yeah.
Have you seen Josh?
He got in the car with Leo.
No, he didn't. Shanahan got in with Leo. Josh didn't get in the car. They part ways. A woman shouts somewhere.
Can we get some help?
Yeah. Stay right there. Toby continues to look around for Josh. He spots the back of his head behind a ledge, away from everyone else. He was sitting beside it. Toby runs to him.

Josh! Didn't you hear me shouting for you? I didn't know where the hell you... As Toby faces his friend, Josh stares at him, gasping for breath, while holding his stomach. A huge amount of blood has come out from his chest, to his shirt and all over his hands. Toby's face changes.
I need a... I need a doctor! I need help! C.J. and Sam heard him and starts to run towards them. Josh suddenly slumps over, his bloody hands still on his gunshot wound.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. GEORGE WASHINGTON HOSPITAL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: It's a quiet night in the hospital lobby. Several patients are sitting in the waiting section. Two nurses meet.

Dialogues.Line: Hey.
Hey. Your best friend's back. The other nurse looks to the waiting section. She notices a familiar patient.
Thank you for that. She walks over to a pregnant woman.
Cynthia. Hi. You can follow me. Cynthia and her nurse walk away. We follow the first nurse as she walks to the reception desk. Another nurse comes.

She's been in twice a week for the last three weeks because she can't feel the baby kick. I should just tell her ma'am, wait till eight months, the kid'll be doing the Macarena. In the meantime, this is an emergency room.
Did you really say that?
No, I'm saying I should've said that. The other nurse walks away as a phone rings. The first nurse answers the local phone in the desk.
Emergency room. Nobody there. Another phone continues to ring. The nurse hangs up and quietly answers a red phone attached to the wall.
Station One.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LIMOUSINE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is now gasping for breath. Ron is shouting on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: We're coming in!
I copy that. Is this a drill?
No!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HOSPITAL - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sirens are heard from a distance.

Dialogues.Line: [into phone] The thing is I have a few patients, not many but I do have a couple of kids with alcohol poisoning. We're expecting more in a bit, so if this is a drill, I'd just assume... The sirens get louder. The nurse looks to the entranceway where several cars and ambulances have already arrived. She hangs up the red phone and picks up the local phone. She punches a button for the P.A.
Trauma One. Trauma One, Blue! Blue! Trauma One, Blue! Go! Nurses and doctors around her start to get busy. A Secret Service Agent enters and approaches the nurse.
You got priorities?
No priorities.
We're gonna need a hand. They're going to the memorial. The nurse turns to the waiting patients.
Okay, people. I need you to follow this man to the van that's waiting... The patients hurry outside as we follow two agents.
Get the south side clear. There are two backdoors and a loading dock. Put two units in the scaffolding, and get some light out there! The agent comes in a room as DR. KELLER comes out.
Get me an ultrasound and a crash cart. We close in on another agent.
Eagle's two minutes away!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Reporters surround Vice President Hoynes in the lobby. He is holding a jersey while posing for the cameras.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. Vice President, could you hold the shirt up a little bit?
Yeah, one of my roommates at S.M.U. is Drew Harper. Anybody know that name?

'72 Olympics in Munich. Well, I played against him at a pick-up game while on the quad, and I thought I'd stuff him with an overhead slam. He sent that ball back at my face like I talked about his sister. The reporters laugh. Hoynes approaches a man and shakes his hand.

Coach, I want to congratulate you and your team in the NCAA on a great season last year. I know you had four starters returning so I'm confident... Several Secret Service Agents come storming inside. Hoynes gets worried.
Excuse me! Everyone stay where you are. Mr. Vice President, would you come with us please? The agents surround Hoynes and escort him outside as the reporters stand puzzled.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Agents cut in a hallway and meet with Abbey, who is rushing down the hall also with other agents.

Dialogues.Line: Mrs. Bartlet.
Is he conscious?
He's conscious and they're moving him to pre-op. He was hit in the side, entry and exit. They go outside, where a car is waiting.
We're on our way.
What about Zoey?
They got her in the car. She's cool. She's on her way to G.W.
Let's go! Let's go! Let's go! The cars screech as they drive away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HOSPITAL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Nurses and paramedics are hurriedly pushing a gurney carrying President Bartlet. We see blood on the side of the his shirt as he groans and tries to catch his breath. Ron is nearby.

Dialogues.Line: He was shot in the abdomen. It's an entry and exit wound.
B.P. 134 over 78. Pulse is 108. What's his pulse ox?
98. Dr. Keller tries to talk to the President.
Mr. President, I'm Dr. Keller. I'm the trauma surgeon on duty. The exit wound is a good indication we like your vital signs.
I swear to God if I don't speak to my daughter in the next five minutes, I'm gonna attack someone.
She's on her way. They enter a trauma room.
[indicating Ron] This guy's got about seven broken bones in his hand, by the way. If somebody wants to give him an aspirin or something...
We're there. The gurney is stopped, and the nurses and doctors hurriedly prepare for the treatment.
Okay, sir, we're just gonna get you stabilized.
Listen, I want you to wait as long as you can before you give me the anesthesia. I need to speak to Leo McGarry before you give me the anesthesia.
He's on his way as well.
I need to ask you some questions, sir. Do you have any medical conditions?
Well... I've been shot.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE CORRIDOR - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: It's a quiet night in the West Wing as Margaret and Mrs. Landingham meet in the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening, Mrs. Landingham.
Good evening, Margaret.
The President's not back yet?
I imagine he's schmoozing the rope line. They enter the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE. Margaret immediately notices a SPECIAL REPORT on the television screen.

You know, he said he's coming straight back, but he can't resist a rope line. Never has. Oh, he'll complain, but he just can't resist it. I remember a time in the Governor's mansion. It was about ten years ago...
[eyes on the TV] Mrs. Landingham.
More. Maybe 12.
Mrs. Landingham! Margaret turns up the volume as Mrs. Landingham watches with her. A newscaster appears on the monitor.

Good evening. We are getting reports that multiple gunshots were fired at President Bartlet as he was leaving a public event in Rosslyn, Virginia. The shots were fired approximately seven minutes ago... Mrs. Landingham runs out of the office before the newscaster could finish.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. TRAUMA ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Zoey walks inside and sees her father in pain. A look of fear is on her face. The nurses are still very busy.

Dialogues.Line: Dad?
I'm okay.
Daddy?!
They didn't hit anything. They're just gonna look around and make sure.
Are you-- are you in a lot of pain?
No.
Are you lying?
Yeah, 'cause I want these guys to tell reporters that I was brave and joking around.
You are brave. You were so good tonight, dad.
[sighs] Honey, I'm fine. I'm just so happy to see you.
Mom's on her way.
Mom's gonna be pretty pissed.
Yeah. All of a sudden, Leo comes storming in the trauma room, a troubling look in his face as he looks at Bartlet. He notices Zoey beside him.
How you doing, kid?
I'm fine.
She booted all over the back of her car. You know they're gonna bill me for that.
Yeah.
Honey, do me a favor, will you?
Yeah. I'll step outside. I'll go wait for mom.
Tell her not to frighten the doctors. I'll see you in a couple hours.
I love you.
I love you too, hon. Zoey exits. Leo walks closer to Bartlet.
Anybody killed back there?
The two shooters. They got them through the window.
Anybody in the crowd?
There were some injuries. They're coming right now.
What about our people?
C.J. hit her head on the ground, but other than that...
[beat] Get the cabinet together and the Security Council. Tell Jerome to suspend trading on the stock exchange.
Yeah.
Do we know who the shooters were?
No.
I'm gonna be under anesthesia for a couple hours.
It'll be fine.
You know what I'm talking about, right?
I'll talk to Abbey.
Sir, it's time.
[to Leo] Hey. Come here. He motions for Leo to come closer. Leo leans his head near him. Bartlet, looking to comfort his best friend, kisses Leo gently on the cheek.
It's okay.
I'll see you in a few hours, Mr. President. Bartlet sighs as Leo exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HOSPITAL LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Zoey is talking to a woman.

Dialogues.Line: Okay, Zoey. I'll find out. The woman leaves. Abbey comes running inside and sees her daughter.
Oh. You all right?
Yeah. They hug tight.
And Dad's making jokes.
Good ones, or...?
No.
Okay. Leo approaches, along with Dr. Keller.
Abbey. This is Dr. Keller.
Oh, yes. We spoke in the car.
Hello.
What's his PO2?
It's good. It's a hundred.
You're gonna do a laperoscopy?
Yeah. We want to make sure the peritoneum's intact.
Mm-hmm. Who's the anesthesiologist?
Dr. Lee.
[to Zoey] You'll be okay honey?
Yeah. Abbey walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TRAUMA ROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Just outside Bartlet's trauma room. DR. LEE is standing. Abbey approaches him.

Dialogues.Line: Dr. Lee?
Dr. Bartlet. I hope they told you that it's looking very good.

There are 14 people in the world who know this, including the vice President, the chief of staff, and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs. You are going to be the fifteenth. Seven years ago, my husband was diagnosed with a relapsing/remitting course of M.S. When all this is over, tell the press, don't tell the press. It's entirely up to you. Abbey immediately exits.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is strolling along the busy hospital. He spots Gina standing by a doorway. He puts his arm up and leans it in the wall.

Dialogues.Line: You all right?
Yeah.
Was there someone on the ground?
There was a signal. I couldn't give a description.
Did they close the airports?
And Union Station. We've got troopers on the bridges and 300 field agents working Rosslyn. I can't tell them what they're looking for. A faint sound of a siren is heard.
You got the girl in the car, Gina.
It's right in front of my face.
Look... The sirens get louder as paramedics and nurses comes in the hospital with another patient.
Gunshot wound! No exit!
He's got decreased breath sounds in the left. Pulse ox is 92 on 15 liters. Leo comes running out the door with several nurses. C.J. and Toby are running beside the gurney.
It's Josh!
I've got the hemocue.
Josh!
Trauma panel, serial crits...
What happened?
He was behind us.
Single gunshot wound, left fifth intercostal space. We hear Sam somewhere.
Josh, I'm here! Josh has an oxygen mask in his mouth. He speaks groggily.
I shouldn't be at this meeting.
Trauma One's ready.
I need a chest tube tray, 32 French.
Senator...
Tell me what's happening!
I don't have time! They come inside TRAUMA ONE.
I shouldn't be at this meeting.
Pulse ox, 88.
I need to get to New Hampshire. Sam is now beside Josh.
You went to New Hampshire. We both did. You came and got me.
On my count. One. Two. Three! We see an OVERHEAD SHOT of Josh being lifted onto another bed. Everything around him switches into SLOW MOTION.
Josh, a bullet collapsed your lung. We're putting in a tube to re-expand it.
We've got blood in the theroseal.
Over a liter and out.
He's bradying down.
Okay, tube him now.
80 E.T. Tube?
Social Security...
Cricoid Pressure...
Senator. As Josh loses consciousness in the trauma room, we --
We find out that the voices are from Josh and Hoynes.
Social Security is...
Senator.
Social Security is the black hole...
Senator.
Social Security--
Senator.
Social Security--
Sir.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE SENATE BUILDING, A CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: An OVERHEAD SHOT from the chandelier in a conference room. Scanning the crowd, Senator John Hoynes of Texas holds a meeting with his staff, including Josh, from

Dialogues.Line: Social Security is the black hole of national politics.
Yes.
Josh was cutting me off because he knew I was gonna say that. He knew I was gonna say that because I have said it, what?
A few hundred times, sir.
It is the black hole of national politics, and I would just assume not get lost in it 13 weeks before the New Hampshire primary. It is the third rail. You step on it, and you die. [sits]
Of the 537 federal election officials, there are 30 who put their names on Social Security reform legislation, and you're one of them. Why not say so?
He will say so. Just not now.

Mark, 400 billion dollars. Social Security represents one-fourth of the federal budget, and it's gonna be bankrupt in exactly 17 years. Right around the time you're going to check your mailbox, half of the elderly population will be living in poverty. This now, qualifies as a priority, and running for President of the United States not putting Social Security front and center is like running for President of the Walt Disney Corporation by saying you're gonna fix the rides at Epcot.
We're gonna get to Social Security, Josh. It's a long campaign. For now, we focus on the tax cuts.
It's what magicians call 'misdirection.'
Really? 'Cause it's what the rest of us call bull--
Knock it off! I have a vote. [stands] The rest of you should stay here and work on the ethanol tax credit. Josh, come with me, would you?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Hoynes is walking with Josh.

Dialogues.Line: You don't seem to be having a very good time lately.
I don't think the point of this is for me to have...
I'm saying you've been pissed off at every meeting for a month. They stop walking.
Senator, you're the prohibitive favorite to be the Democratic Party's nominee for President. You have 58 million dollars in war chest with no end in sight, and... I don't know what we're for.
Josh.
I don't know what we're for, and I don't know what we're against. Except we seem to be for winning and against somebody else winning.
It's a start.
Senator...

Josh, we are going to run a good campaign. You're gonna be very proud of it. When we get to the White House, you're gonna play a big role. In the meantime, cheer up, and get off my ass about Social Security. I've got a vote. Hoynes walks away, leaving Josh in the hallway.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SENATE BUILDING OFFICES - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh wanders around the place. A familiar voice calls to him -- Leo McGarry.

Dialogues.Line: Josh.
Mr. Secretary!
I hope you don't mind I didn't make an appointment. I'm trying to fly under the radar a little.
Of course, I don't mind, but the senator just went down for the 404 vote.
It's probably the annual vote override to veto on the resolution to ship nuclear wastes to Nevada.
Yeah.
It won't pass.
No kidding.
Actually, I came to see you.
Really?
Yeah.
What can I do for you?
You mind if we take a walk?
Sure.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE CAPITOL BUILDING - DAY
Scenes.Description: Just outside the building, near the Washington Monument, Josh and Leo are walking.

Dialogues.Line: I heard your dad was in the hospital again.
Yeah. They put... they got it all this time.
Is he taking it easy?
No. He goes to the office at seven in the morning and goes home at eight every night. On the weekends, he cleans the gutters and yells at the squirrels.
Why does he yell at the squirrels?
'Cause they eat the seeds out of the bird feeder.
You know, they make a thing now... They stop walking.
He knows, but he prefers to admonish them. But, listen, I-I need to get back to this meeting.
Josh, I'd like you to come to Nashua, New Hampshire Thursday night and hear Jed Bartlet speak.
I work for Senator Hoynes.
Yeah.
Mr. Secretary...
I'm not in the Cabinet anymore, Josh. Call me Leo.
Look, Hoynes has the nomination sewn up.
Yeah.
And if Bartlet's looking to be Treasury Secretary or a slot at the Convention, this really isn't...
Come to Nashua Thursday night.
Why?
Because that's what sons do for old friends of their fathers. [starts to walk away]
Mr. Secretary...
Leo. [stops and looks back]
Leo, the-the Democrats aren't gonna nominate another liberal academic former governor from New England. I mean, we're dumb, but we're not that dumb.

[beat] Nah. I think we're exactly that dumb. Leo heads on his way, leaving Josh puzzled. After a moment, Josh pulls out his cell phone and dials a number as he walks up the stairs of the Capitol Building.
[into phone] Yeah, uh, Janet. Uh, I need you to set up some plane tickets to New York. Uh, probably to Boston too... The camera PANS UP to the top of the Capitol Building.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. A LAW FIRM - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Sam is in a meeting with several lawyers, including his boss MR. GAGE, MR. LOCH and
All in, showroom floor to your garage, 18 million dollars.
18 million dollars is a cheap price, isn't it?
Yes, it is. What you're happy about isn't the price. It's the structure of the deal.
Well, how do you figure that?
Sam's going to tell you about it. Sam. Sam looks up quickly.
Hmm?
Structure versus cost?
Uh, yeah. What Jack means is, if you were getting the tankers for a buck 85 and trading stamps it would still be a bad deal if we didn't limit your liability.
And you did that?
We did.
How?
The same way we do with any other asset acquisition. Create a separate corporation for each one of them, then mortgage the boats, top to bottom.
Ships.
I'm sorry?
Oil tankers aren't boats, they're ships.
Mr. Cameron, you want me to buy the boats, you're not asking me to be the first mate, right?
No.

You want to finance the tankers a hundred percent so that if litigation does penetrate the liability shield we've set up for you there are no real assets at the end of the line, just debt. You're judgment proof. Let me run back to my office and get the tax figures while David and Rita talk about IMO regulations. [exits]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam walks by the corridor where a secretary meets him.

Dialogues.Line: Sam. There's a guy waiting in your office who said he's a friend of yours.
What's his name?
Josh Lyman?
[looks surprised] Seriously?
Yeah. Sam enters his office, where Josh is standing.
Hey!
How you doing? They hug.
Hey, you look fit.
You made partner?
Next month. Listen, I'm hungry. You want to go grab a hot dog or something?
It's 9:30 in the morning.
Yeah, they'll be fresh. Come on.
Okay.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. MANHATTAN STREET - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and Josh are walking away from a hot dog stand.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah, I was going to call before I came here, but then the strangest thing happened. Sam throws out his hot dog wrapper.
What?
I forgot the name of your firm.
Gage Whitney.
Yeah.
You couldn't remember Gage Whitney.
I know.
Second biggest firm in New York?
I know.
Did the Shearson deal--
Yeah.
Bought Transcom.
I really do know Gage Whitney. I'm saying, I'm just, um, I'm um, having a brain problem.
What are you doing in town?
I'm on my way to Nashua.
What's in Nashua?
Ah, a waste of time. Listen. You know why I'm here.
You want me to quit my job and come work for Hoynes?
He's gonna win, Sam.
So what do you need me for?
A better campaign. Come do some speech writing.
Lisa and I are getting married in September. They stop.
[looks surprised] Ah.
[grins] Yeah.
Okay. Listen, I should go, I got to go. I should let you--
I got to get back to this thing.
It's good seeing you.
It's good seeing you. I miss you. They start to walk in separate directions.
Hey, congratulations on that partnership.
Josh! They turn and face each other.
Hoynes. He's not the real thing, is he?
See, that-the thing you gotta know about Hoynes is-- [approaches him]
It's okay.
I-I'm saying--
Josh. [beat] What are you doing?
I don't know. What are you doing?
Protecting oil companies from litigation. Josh nods.
They're our client. They don't lose legal protection because they make a lot of money.
I can't believe no one ever wrote a folk song about that. Sam grins.
If I see the real thing in Nashua, should I tell you about it?
You won't have to.
Why?
You've got a pretty bad poker face.
Okay. [starts walking off] Take it easy.
Okay. Sam turns around and plows into a woman before we--

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HOSPITAL - PRESENT
Scenes.Description: Sam has just rammed into a nurse.

Dialogues.Line: I'm sorry.
That's okay.
I'm sorry. It's just-- A man in a suit, who we'll assume is a doctor, approaches Abbey.
Dr. Bartlet. <><>
Yes.
The President's going to be fine.
Oh. [sighs in relief]
You can see him in the recovery room in about two hours. The two of them start walking.
Thank you. No organ damage?
No ma'am, and blood loss was minimal. Dr. Keller was able to visualize the entire abdomen, and he's secure with the diagnostic of the laparoscopy. Abbey stops and turns.
What about Josh?
The bullet lacerated his pulmonary artery.
Can they try a Gortex graft?
No. They're going to have to stay in and try to repair the artery primarily.
Thank you. Abbey enters the waiting room and addresses everyone inside.

The President's going to be fine. The bullet seems to have gone out of it's way not to hit anything. Now, here's what's happening with Josh... A Secret Service Agent closes the door to the waiting room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo and a man in uniform, Jack, are on a TV monitor starting to enter the room.

Dialogues.Line: Thank you.
What do you know?
He'll be out of surgery in about two hours. Fitzwallace is on a plane?
He was on his way to Manila. They turned around, and he'll be back in about four hours.
We've got him by phone?
Yeah. They enter the situation room full of busy military men.
Good evening.
Good evening, Mr. McGarry.
Where's the National Security Advisor?

She's on her way. So's the Vice President. NANCY McNALLY, the National Security Advisor, enters, wearing a dressy yellow suit. NANCY McNALLY Good evening everybody. Mike, could you have somebody send over some clothes from my office, please? I look like an idiot.
Yes ma'am. Nancy sits down.
Nancy, you've seen the KH-10 pictures?
Yeah.
And you know what they mean?
Well, I wouldn't go that far. Hoynes enters the room.
Good evening, Mr. Vice President.
Good evening Nancy. Leo.
Jack. Hoynes pauses at the head of the table.
Ten Hut! Hoynes looks up, a little surprised as the people in the room stand.
No, as you were. It's-it's okay. [sits to the side of the head of the table] Bobby, your report on domestic activity?

Yes, sir. There's not much. Air traffic control was down for 22 minutes at Logan. City bank computers were off-line for a little more than an hour, and the lights went out for seven minutes at the Delta Center.
Somebody tell me-these shooters, they didn't have a wallet on them? They didn't have a driver's license?
They didn't have anything on them, Mr. Vice President. They knew we were gonna get them through the window.
If this signal guy isn't in custody in one hour, I'm going to federalize the Virginia and Maryland National Guards.
It's worth mentioning that at this moment we do not know the whereabouts of about a half dozen cell leaders, including bin Laden, but that's not my concern right now.
What is your concern?
Can we look at the KH-10's?
I've seen them. I'm not worried about it.
Leo, these images show a sudden build-up of front-line Republican guard units along the Tigress and Euphrates Rivers.
The build-up isn't sudden. They do it every couple of months.

And they're moving south. Now thirteen hours ago they shot down an F-117 in the No-Fly. The rescue mission invaded their airspace with armed M-50 Pave Hawks. And my recommendation would be that the President order Fitzwallace to put the 32nd tactical on ready alert and take us to Defcon 4.
The President is under general anesthesia right now. If he weren't I'm sure he'd be comforted to know that RDF can put Marines on the ground in 36 hours.
We may not have 36 hours.
The Iraqi Republican guard can't find their car keys in 36 hours.
Look at the pictures, Mr. Vice-President. I think they've found 'em. Hoynes pauses for several moments.
Nancy, we're gonna follow Leo for the moment.
Jack, what's the best way to get a message to Iraq?
The king of Jordan.
All right.
Leo. What do you want the message to be? LEO<> Don't mess with us tonight.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. G.W. HOSPITAL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The same doctor enters the waiting room where Sam, Toby, C.J., Charlie and the rest of the staff are waiting.

Dialogues.Line: Uh, excuse me. Everyone looks up.
We can't make you very comfortable here, and Josh's procedure is likely to take 12 to 14 hours. So-- Donna enters the room.
I'm sorry, they told me I should come back here? I'm sorry. Is there word on the President?
The President's going to be fine.

Oh, thank God. [sighs] Oh, thank God, that's the best news I've ever heard. I got here as fast as I could. I had a hard time getting in. I had-I had to find an agent who knew me, and I was shaking. I was just -- I didn't know-- TOBY<> Donna. [beat] Josh was hit.
Hit with what?
He was shot--in the chest.
He's in surgery right now.
I don't understand. I don't understand, is -- is it serious?
Yes, it's critical. The bullet collapsed his lung and damaged a major artery. Donna looks very shocked.

I was just saying, we can't make you very comfortable here, and the procedure's likely to take 12 to 14 hours. We won't know anything until morning. I'm sure there are things you're supposed to be attending to right now, so if you like we can stay in contact with your homes and offices throughout the night. As the doctor exits, Donna sinks into a chair and stares into space. C.J. begins to rub her back. Sam tears a piece of paper out of his notebook hands it to C.J.
Leo's gonna meet with the leadership in ten minutes. When he's done, I'll talk to the press.
I'm gonna go back to the residence and pick up some things for the President. Charlie and C.J. stand up and exit the room. Donna is still sitting and staring into space.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. PRESS ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J is doing a briefing, but she looks somewhat dazed, like she's still in shock.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.!
Yeah.
When can we talk to the medical team?
Dr. Keller, the head surgeon, and Admiral Jarvis, the President's personal physician, will be debriefing you in a few hours.
C.J.!
Danny!
Has there been any discussion of the 25th amendment?
No--
C.J.!
[talking over reporters] Why not?
What?
Why hasn't there been any discussion of the 25th amendment?
I'll get back to you on that.
C.J.!
Do you have anything on the identity of the shooters?
I'm sorry?
Do you have anything on the identity of the shooters?
No.
Are you aware that the AP has been saying that two bodies were brought out of the building?
I don't have anything for you on that.
Are you also aware that the AP is also saying there is now a massive manhunt underway for a suspected third accomplice?
I don't have anything for you on that either.
C.J.!
Why does the AP know more than you do?
I don't believe the AP knows more than I do; I just believe they're willing to tell you more. Carol leans over and tells C.J. something.
One more question!
C.J.!
Arthur!

In previous administrations the President entered and exited buildings under a tent or canopy, the Secret Service wanting to limit visibility in the open air. Can you tell me why these precautions weren't taken for President Bartlet or at least not tonight?
It's policy not to comment on security procedures.
Well, C.J., if you can't answer the most straightforward question then what can you tell us?
I'm sorry?
What do you know? What can you tell us? C.J. has her hand on her neck and looks dazed.
[pause] There'll be another briefing in an hour and a half. Hopefully we'll know more then. The reporters groan as she announces this, and some try calling her.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Carol are walking down the hall towards C.J.'s office.

Dialogues.Line: [muttering to herself] What's that supposed to mean since you can't answer my question?
You scratched your neck.
What?
You have scratch on the side of your neck.
I lost my necklace. It must have come off when.
When what?
Somebody pushed me down. Danny comes up behind them as they turn the corner into a HALLWAY.
C.J.? Carol heads off while Danny and C.J. walk through the communications area still towards her office.
What?
I'm sorry, I don't want to be a reporter for a few minutes but you've gotta answer my question.
What was the question?
The President's been under anesthetic for more than an hour. He's probably gonna be on a morphine drip. Without the 25th, who's in charge?
The Vice President, the Secretary of State, the National Security Advisor, the Secretary of Defense, one of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the White House Chief of Staff.
You just listed six people! Who's in charge?
The Canadiens.
You understand I'm talking about the hockey team.
Look.
Just... give me a little time. Danny nods. C.J. walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Nancy and Leo are arguing. C.J. and Toby are with them.

Dialogues.Line: Fitzwallace agrees with me, Nancy. Upgrade our DefCon posture and the whole world's gonna wake up.

The world's already awake Leo! Look at the TV. Look out the window! They had more than one shooter. We think they had a guy on the ground. If they had one, there's no reason to believe they didn't have more than one. Somebody had to get them into that office. This was not a lonely guy who lived with his cats. There was a plan and one of the things we have to assume is that we're under attack right now.
Which is why the Vice President should order the 32nd tactical on a ready alert and take us to DefCon 4.
Counsel's office isn't sure he can do that.
Why not?
He never signed a letter.
What letter?
Customarily if the President is going to be under anesthetic.
He's gotta sign a letter giving the Vice President power?
Absent of the 25th, the Constitution doesn't give it to him unless the President is dead.
He's hemorrhaging and he's supposed to draft a memo?
Yeah.
I'm getting questions from Danny Concannon on it.
It gets more complicated if you'd read section 202 the National Securities Act of 1947.
Let's assume I haven't.
It says the Secretary of Defense will be the principal assistant to the President on all matters relating to national security.
And what does 'principal assistant' mean?
It doesn't specify.
Of course it wouldn't, 'cause that's an area of federal law where he'd want to have as much ambiguity as possible.
Yeah.
Excuse me. [leaves]
I'm gonna go back to the hospital.
I'll be there in a little bit.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby is entering something onto a handheld device as he walks. C.J. catches up with him.

Dialogues.Line: Try and hold Danny off for a few hours until the Counsel's office tells us where we are.
Okay.
You scratched your neck.
What?
Your neck.
Yeah, it's where my necklace. Listen, Toby, I've been getting some questions about the canopy the Secret Service used to use for outdoor entrances and exits. They stop walking.
Who asked you?
It was. Arthur Leeds, then a couple of others stopped me.
Okay. They start walking again.
We don't comment on security procedures.
Yeah.
So I don't think I'll have to answer that question.
Yeah.
Okay.
I'll see you at the hospital.
Yeah. C.J. walks away. Toby goes into the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
I need section 202 of the National Securities Act of 1947. He notices Ginger, who is standing by her desk.
Hey Ginger. I didn't know you were here.
I just... I turned on the T.V. Her hands are shaking. She looks very upset and scared.
It's okay. [pause] Come here. He gives her a big hug.
It's okay.
I'm sorry.
You all right?
Yeah.
Ready to go to work?
[nods and half-smiles] Yeah. Toby enters his office and Ginger goes to a desk.
You want another one of those?
What?
I didn't say anything.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. A DARK BAR - DAY

Dialogues.Line: You want another one of those?
Yeah. HANK'S TAVERN NASHUA, NH
Toby and a woman are sitting at the bar. Toby looks pretty drunk and is smoking a cigar. The bartender pours some more of Toby's drink.
I gotta tell you.
Yeah.
I didn't even know Bartlet was running.
Yeah, we kept that secret pretty good. You know, he's speaking at the VFW hall tonight. You should come.
I'm not very political.
There'll be free chicken.
You've been a... um, uh, what did you call it?
Professional political operative.
You've been one your whole life.
Well, there was a while back there when I was in elementary school. The woman laughs.
You any good?
[long pause] Yes, I'm very good.
What's your record?
My record?
How many elections have you won?
Altogether? The woman nods.
Including city council, two Congressional elections, a senate race, a Gubernatorial campaign, and a national campaign? There's a long pause.
...None.
None of them?
You gotta be impressed with my consistency.
So, let me ask you something.
Sure.
How come you're drinking so much so early in the day?
Cause I'm about to get fired. Toby finishes his drink, puts some money on the counter, and picks up his coat.
It was nice meeting you. [leaves the bar]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. VFW HALL - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: NASHUA, NH
Bartlet is speaking. Several people are seated and eating.

...Consumer price index, we tend to be late in responding to these trends, and we get what doctors call a "false positive". The science of economics is a lot less an exact science that we pretend. We build complex models with thousands of interdependent and independent variables. Toby is seated near a corner. Another member of Bartlet's staff, CAL MATHIS, approaches.
What's he gonna say?
About what?
If he's asked the question.
What question?
New England D.F.C.
I don't know.
You talked to him, didn't you?
Yeah.
What's he gonna say?
I don't know.
You talked to him about the New England D.F.C. if he's asked?
Yes.
You wrote him a memo.
Yes.
So what's he gonna say?
I have no new information since the last time you asked me that question. Bartlet is now speaking to a woman, who is standing.

Let me put it another way: you and your husband pay $600 more every year than you would if you were unmarried, living together, and filing individually. Couples living outside the covenant of marriage do so. Josh is in the back of the room, reading a newspaper. Cal and Toby are still talking.
You told him to go ahead and piss off the dairy farmers, didn't you? Toby just looks at him.
If he's asked about the New England D.F.C, you told him to piss off the dairy farmers.
I asked him about his vote, he told me, I said then if he's asked about it tonight he should and only because it's the easiest thing to remember, tell the truth.
Do you enjoy losing?
Not that much, but then I haven't had much to compare it to so... Cal walks off. Bartlet continues talking to the woman.
...which then again is a much larger tax on overstated real profits.
Yes.
You really didn't understand any of that, right?
A little.
Me too. Yeah? The man who raised his hand stands up.
Governor Bartlet, when you were a member of Congress, you voted against the New England Dairy Farming Compact. That vote hurt me sir. Cal looks over at Toby.

I'm a businessman. That vote hurt me to the tune of maybe, 10 cents a gallon. I voted for you three times for Congress. I voted for you twice for Governor. We see Josh again, still reading the newspaper.
And I'm here sir, and I'd like to ask you for an explanation.
[pause] Yeah, I screwed you on that one. Josh looks up, surprised.
I'm sorry?
I screwed you. You got hosed.
Sir, I...
And not just you. A lot of my constituents. I put the hammer to farms in Concord, Salem, Laconia, and Elem. Josh looks really shocked and is now watching Bartlet.
You guys got rogered but good. The man sits down.
Today, for the first time in history, one in five Americans living in poverty are children. We see a still surprised Josh.

One in five children live in the most abject, dangerous, hopeless, backbreaking, gut wrenching, poverty, one in five, and they're children. If fidelity to freedom and democracy is the code of our civic religion then surely, the code of our humanity is faithful service to that unwritten commandment that says "We shall give our children better than we ourselves had." I voted against the bill 'cause I didn't want it to be hard for people to buy milk. I stopped some money from flowing into your pocket. If that angers you, if you resent me, I completely respect that, but if you expect anything different from the President of the United States, I suggest you vote for somebody else. Thanks very much. Hope you enjoyed the chicken. The audience applauds. Josh claps too.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. GEORGE WASHINGTON HOSPITAL - PRESENT
Scenes.Description: TUESDAY, 1:45 A.M. A car drives past. INT. BARTLET'S HOSPITAL ROOM - NIGHT Ron opens the door for Leo.

Dialogues.Line: Jed, please. I want you to lie still for a few hours.
Mr. President?
I wanna see him.
[to Abbey] Is he okay?
I told him about Josh.
Please. Help me to the door.
You should stay in bed.
Charlie brought me some clothes. Please let me see him. Abbey looks at Dr. Keller. He nods.
Okay. Just for a minute.
Great. He starts to get up.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. VFW HALL, NASHUA, N.H. - NIGHT, THREE YEARS EARLIER
Scenes.Description: After the speech, Leo, Cal, Toby, Bartlet, and the rest of his staff are having a meeting.

Dialogues.Line: What's next?
The thing about saying the name.
I understand.
If I could just reframe the point that Cal was making.
I understand the point that Cal was making. I was sitting next to him when he made it, my ears are connected to my brain just like every body else. And I'm saying what's next?
Sir, not to put my head in the lion's mouth but by saying the name of your opponent in public you're essentially giving him free advertising.
Cal thinks you should start referring to him as "my opponent" or "the other guy"?
Sir.
You're not afraid he's gonna make me look like I can't remember his name?
No.

I am. I think it's going to make me look like I can't remember his name. I think it's going to make me look addled. I think it's going to make me look dotty. And even if it didn't make me look like those things it would remain a stupid idea. What's next? Nothing? Excellent. [leaves]
Okay, what's next?
Leo, we have to talk about what happened tonight.
I think he did well. I would of liked to have seen more of those seats filled.
That's not what I'm talking about.
What're you talking about?
He's talking about the Governor's answer tonight. Everybody looks at Toby.
I'm just guessing. I'm pretty drunk.
I am talking about the Governor's answer tonight. But I'm also talking about. Every day there's some. Look, Toby, we can talk about this in the room or if you're more comfortable we can--
Listen, I don't have time to make people comfortable. If a change has to be made, it has to be made. Jerry, Cal, Mack, Steve -- you're fired.
What?
What?
No kidding. It's moving day. I want Toby. The rest of you-- thanks very much. They all stare at Leo.
Fellas. Look at my face. You're done. Everyone except Leo and Toby leaves.
[to Toby] Don't screw up. Leo exits. Toby is sitting alone under the light.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. SIDEWALK OUTSIDE THE VFW HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo joins Bartlet outside.

Dialogues.Line: Its freezing cold in October! I don't know how you people live here.
Did you just fire Cal Mathis?
Yeah.
You fired him.
Yeah, and Jerry, and Mack, and Steve and the other guy.
Is there anyone you kept?
I kept Toby Ziegler.
Oh, you kept Toby Ziegler, and you fired everyone else.
Yeah.
Toby Ziegler is the only person working for us I don't know, and he's the one you kept!
Take him home, would you?
Those were the only people I know.
Those people were worthless. It's time we bring in what we need.
So you made that decision on your own.
Yeah. You know why? 'Cause you're a crappy politician. I think you'll find I'll be making a lot of decisions on my own so get used to it.
You know I got elected to Congress by this state. This state sent me to Congress three times and elected me Governor all without your help. LEO starts grinning.
Don't start!
No, seriously, that's a real political accomplishment, considering that your family founded this state.
Hey.
Were you even opposed in any of those elections?
You got rid of all the people I know!
Yeah. Have a good night. Leo walks off. Bartlet follows.

Why are you doing this? You're a player. You're bigger in the party than I am. Hoynes would make you national chairman. Leo! Tell me this isn't one of the twelve steps. Leo turns around to face his friend.
Yeah, that's what it is. Right after admitting we're powerless over alcohol and that a higher power can restore us to sanity, that's where you come in.
Leo.

Because I'm tired of it year after year after year after year having to chose between the lesser of who cares? Of trying to get myself excited about a candidate who can speak in complete sentences. Of setting the bar so low, I can hardly look at it. They say a good man can't get elected President. I don't believe that, do you?
And you think I'm that man.
Yes.
Does it matter that I'm not as sure?
Nah. Act as if ye have faith and faith shall be given to you. Put it another way, fake it till you make it. You did good tonight.
Yeah. They start walking again.
This is the time of Jed Bartlet, old friend. You're gonna open your mouth and lift houses off the ground. Whole houses, clear off the ground... They continue to walk down the street as we --
INT. G.W. HOSPITAL HALLWAY - PRESENT Bartlet and Leo are slowly walking down the hospital hall. Music has started, and we hear several news reports.
And it's unknown at this time whether the President before going under anesthesia signed a letter that would give temporary custody.
...between George Washington Hospital and the White House where several thousand people have... A big number of people are gathered in the streets.
...begun to gather behind police barricades. An impromptu TV vigil with prayers being made... We see Sam in his office, staring at his desk.
...and collective breath being held. We fade to Toby, in his office, as he puts his hands on his face.
Clearly, I think, and understandably rocked on their heels at this hour, to put it mildly. We see C.J. in her office, staring into space, her hand scratching her neck.
Press Secretary C.J. Cregg appeared at her briefings to be shaken and withdrawn.

...officials at George Washington Hospital. And in the third hour of a massive manhunt for a third suspect, airports up and down the Atlantic Coast are closed. In Rosslyn, FBI agents and cops are searching the area.
Major delays, cancellations, and closures at major airports, rail stations... Massive traffic is seen in a Washington street.
...and bus stations, and harbors. Travelers are strongly advised to wait. In the Situation Room, military men are discussing tactics.
...Two navy carrier groups as well as the 32nd marine tactical division have been put on heightened alert.

...Secret Service agent Ron Butterfield, head of the President's Secret Service detail, who was shot in the hand during the attack. We see Ron and Gina outside the waiting room in the G.W. Hospital. Inside, Mrs. Landingham has her hand over Donna's. They are silently sitting next to each other.
INT. JOSH'S OPERATION ROOM - NIGHT Busy surgeons surround the unconscious Josh. Bartlet and Leo looks through the window.
Look what happened. There is much concern on their faces as we slowly --

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
